Post Text: I see many guides and examples of using ChatGPT and Claude for CV screening, from AI influencers, HR Tech professionals and startups building on top of LLMs. This is awful. Most guides go like this:- Copy the job description- Copy 3-5 parsed resumes- Write a detailed prompt asking GPT to compare the profiles to the job description.- Paste all these in GPT and save tons of time with the results.This is a bit concerning for a few reasons:- This is probably illegal in quite a few countries, because LLMs are black boxes and there is no explainability or interpretability as to how the screening results are generated- LLMs get worse with extended context, so pasting 10-20 pages of text decreases the quality of response and parts of your prompt will be cut off anyway with GPT3.5.- Bias – LLMs are trained on vast datasets that inevitably contain biases present in the source material – this has been shown multiple times in different studies, including recruiting cases.- Sharing candidate private data with GPT without their consentWith some advanced implementation, specific problems above can be fixed, like removing personal data or using advanced models to reduce context limitation size.However, the worst problem here is a fundamental lack of understanding of how LLMs work. The absence of real-world awareness or common sense reasoning in LLMs is a critical drawback in screening profiles.While LLMs can process and generate text based on patterns, they do not understand the text in the human sense. Their "understanding" is limited to statistical correlations between words and phrases in their training data. LLMs operate strictly within the scope of the text data on which they have been trained. There is no guarantee that your specific use case is covered with enough qualitative data.Does this mean that LLMs cannot help with candidate screening? Not really. In practical terms, LLMs can assist in screening by automating the identification of relevant qualifications and experiences in CVs that can be used as input further along the screening cycle. They can also be used as natural language interfaces during initial communication with the candidate to verify specific requirements. In recruiting, LLMs should augment people’s work, not fully substitute it. They should not be relied upon to make final hiring decisions without human oversight. #ai #llms #screening #recruiting #chatgpt #claude
Comment: Using LLMs for CV screening requires caution and human oversight to avoid potential legal and bias issues.

Post Text: 𝐔𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐃𝐞𝐧𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐳𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧: 𝐆𝐫𝐨𝐜𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐒𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐠𝐲 🛒Imagine you're in a grocery store where everything is neatly organized by type in different sections. This is like when data is organized in a database, making it easy to find things. But sometimes, it's not very convenient. You might need to go to different sections of the store to get everything on your shopping list.Now, imagine the store starts selling meal kits. These kits have everything you need for a specific recipe all bundled together. It's like having redundant data because some items might appear in more than one kit. But it saves you time and effort because you can grab everything you need for a meal in one go.Normalization is a design principle that helps eliminate redundant data and ensure data integrity. However, there are times when denormalization, the intentional introduction of redundant data, can be a powerful technique to optimize database performance. Denormalization is particularly useful in scenarios where read performance is critical, such as:➡️ Reporting and Analytics: Denormalized data structures can significantly improve the performance of complex analytical queries by reducing the need for joins and aggregations.➡️ Content Management Systems: Storing denormalized content data can enhance the speed of content retrieval and rendering, improving the user experience.➡️ Real-time Applications: Applications that require low-latency data access, such as stock trading platforms or gaming systems, can benefit from denormalized data structures.

Carrie James & Emily Weinstein are exceptional people to follow if you want to understand more about teens' perspectives on this issue. When I spoke to some sixth formers at an academy in Greater London recently about this, as well as the solutions that Jonathan Haidt poses in his book ‘The Anxious Generation’ & the proposal being considered by UK ministers to ban smartphones, they were far more erudite and practical than many ‘experts’ I’ve listened to. Here are some of their reflections:1. ‘It would be a bit weird having no access to smartphones until you’re 16, then all of a sudden get given it in Year 11….some kids in September, and some in June -how does that work?’ ….Ummm, no idea!2. ‘Could there not be some sort of continuum, so like when you are 12 – you get a phone to text and call and have UberEats on it (!), then when you’re 14, you get Instagram and more stuff like that, and then when you’re 16 – you get what I’m saying?’…Yes, imminently sensible!3. ‘I think the alternatives need to be more compelling – then it’s not so negative. There doesn’t seem to be much of a focus on that, it’s just what you can’t/shouldn’t do’ …Absolutely, this more balanced approach would be more positive, effective and less conflict-generating. 4. ‘If they do this ban thing, what about google searching – are they going to ban that too, cause you can find loads of stuff on there that isn’t great too?’….Hmmm - not sure where they are going to slot that in!5. ‘Social media can bring up insecurities and speed up insecurities, but this is WAY worse when you are young – like in Year 7-10’…Educators, get these brilliant older students into primary schools to speak to parents and children6. ‘My willpower is rubbish, I just can’t resist looking at TikTok when I’m trying to do some work that’s hard or boring’…dismiss the concept of willpower as a way of regulating social media use, highlight that this is like trying to herd cats & focus on forming healthy digital habits instead (Pete Etchells - excellent voice on this)7. ‘Won’t the tech companies fight it? Will it be passed in time for when my little sister comes here?’….Tech companies will pose anything that threatens their profits. I don't know how long such legislation would take, but is there a chance your little sister would be in university before a smartphone ban for U16's came into force? Yes probably.I look forward to speaking to more students in the coming weeks to be further enlightened & draw together some simple principles to help guide discussions in schools & in families, to help children who are teenagers today, to thrive tomorrow.#teenagersnow #digitalagency Bettina Hohnen
Comment: Empowering teenagers to navigate social media challenges is crucial for their well-being and development.
